bestBHT.bht: The parable spoken to the people uses the imagery of a vineyard as a symbol for the people of Israel. The husbandmen in the parable represent the spiritual guides responsible for nurturing righteousness. The phrase for a long time refers to the significant period from the settlement of the Israelites in Canaan to the time of Christ, which lasted around fourteen to fifteen hundred years. This parable emphasizes the privileged position and numerous blessings enjoyed by the Jewish people under the previous dispensation.

Henry Alford: The parable was spoken to the people."
He addressed it to the people, to guard against interruption on the part of the chief priests.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: vineyard—(See on :-). In Matthew 21:33 additional points are given, taken literally from Matthew 21:33- :, to fix down the application and sustain it by Old Testament authority.
husbandmen—the ordinary spiritual guides of the people, under whose care and culture the fruits of righteousness might be yielded.
went, &c.—leaving it to the laws of the spiritual husbandry during the whole length of the Jewish economy.
Marvin Vincent: Let it out. See on Matthew 21:33.
Went into a far country. Not necessarily far, but as Rev., another country. See on Mark 13:34.
A long time [ικανους] . See on ch. Luke 7:6.
Philip Schaff: After the discomfiture of the priests, scribes, and elders.
To the people, but 'against' His assailants, who were undoubtedly present.
The description of the vineyard is not so full here, but for a long time is new.
Archibald T. Robertson: Vineyard (αμπελωνα). Late word from αμπελος (vine), place of vines.
Let it out (εξεδετο). Second aorist middle of εκδιδωμ, but with variable vowel ε in place of ο of the stem δο (εξεδοτο).
For a long time (χρονους ικανους). Accusative of extent of time, considerable times or periods of time.
John Gill: The people of the Jews are designed by the vineyard, and the 'certain man', or 'householder', as Matthew calls him, is the Lord of hosts; and the planting of it is to be understood of his bringing and settling the people Israel in the land of Canaan."
The care that was taken to cultivate and protect it signify the various blessings and privileges the Jews enjoyed under the former dispensation.

For a long time it was, from the times of Moses and Joshua, when the first settlement, both of the civil and ecclesiastical state of the Jews, was made, to the time of Christ; it was fourteen or fifteen hundred years.
John Wesley: A long time — It was a long time from the entrance of the Israelites into Canaan to the birth of Christ. Matthew 21:33; Mark 12:1.

bhtAttempts.bht: The parable in Luke 20:9 was spoken to the people, specifically to guard against interruption by the chief priests. It uses the imagery of a vineyard to represent the people of Israel and the Lord as the householder. The husbandmen in the parable symbolize the spiritual guides entrusted with the care of the people and the cultivation of righteousness. The householder goes into another country, symbolizing the spiritual husbandry during the Jewish economy. The phrase for a long time refers to the extensive period from the settlement of the Israelites in Canaan to the time of Christ, encompassing about fourteen to fifteen hundred years. This parable emphasizes the privileged position and the multiple blessings enjoyed by the Jews under the previous dispensation.

The parable in question is directed towards the people, as a way to prevent any disruption from the chief priests. It illustrates a vineyard representing the people of Israel and a householder symbolizing the Lord, while the husbandmen represent the spiritual guides responsible for the people's growth in righteousness. By stating that the householder went to another country for a long time, it signifies the enduring nature of the Jewish economy and the extensive period that elapsed from the settlement of the Israelites in Canaan to the birth of Christ, around fourteen to fifteen hundred years. This parable highlights the immense blessings and privileges enjoyed by the Jews throughout this time.

The parable in Luke 20:9 is addressed to the people to prevent interruption from the chief priests. It uses the imagery of a vineyard to represent the people of Israel, with the husbandmen symbolizing the spiritual guides responsible for cultivating righteousness. The phrase for a long time denotes the extensive period, lasting around fourteen to fifteen hundred years, from the settlement of the Israelites in Canaan to the time of Christ. This parable highlights the privileged position and numerous blessings enjoyed by the Jewish people under the previous dispensation.

It uses a vineyard as a representation of the people of Israel, with the husbandmen symbolizing the spiritual guides for cultivating righteousness. The phrase for a long time alludes to the extensive period, spanning around fourteen to fifteen hundred years, from the settlement of the Israelites in Canaan to the time of Christ. This parable emphasizes the privileged position and numerous blessings enjoyed by the Jews under the former dispensation.
